Portfolio BigText

BigText is insane with impressive possibilities for creatives

Imagine moving to a new country and looking for a place to live. Where would you start? If you had no family or friends in a particular location, your decision would most likely be very objective, and would be somewhere that you could find a job and buy a home to take care of yourself (and maybe your family). Being able to find & land a job as well as buy a house are probably at the top of your list.

Earlier this week, Glassdoor.com published one of their periodic “state of the job state” articles, entitled 25 Best Cities For Jobs, but maybe a more proper title would have been: “Where you should live if you’re looking for a job” (OK, maybe something a bit more professional than that). Glassdoor ranks each of the top 25 cities based on a few career & living variables, but does not expose the formula for rating each one. To that end, I determined it was necessary to create a few derivative metrics for people looking to relocate, especially as mentioned, those with no particular affinity to any city. With that I present the three metrics of relocation: Affordability, Obtainability, and Livability.

Affordability

Excluding all other considerations, the main determinant of Affordability in any area is normally housing. It is the heaviest weighted variable in every study or index of how expensive a city is. However for the sake of this argument, we are going past a single variable to determine affordability. I went ahead and redefined Affordability by the ratio of the median housing price to the median base salary in an area, basically the multiple of how many years you would need to spend every single cent of your paycheck (again excluding taxes, Social Security, bonuses, etc.) to pay off your house. By this metric, the top five cities to move to are (in order, with multiple):

  1. Memphis, TN (2.55x)
  2. Pittsburgh, PA (2.9)
  3. Indianapolis, IN (2.96)
  4. St. Louis, MO (2.96)
  5. Kansas City, MO (3.01)

Memphis comes in squarely first, with a 2.55x multiple of salary to house ratio. If you have any aspirations of living in Southeast America, then the Bluff City is for you. The others in the top five all come in at or near 3x the median salary in terms of affordability, meaning acquiring the American Dream is certainly within reach here.

Perhaps not surprising, these cities (and the shaded region that they create) fit easily in a map of America’s “Rust Belt“, traditionally depressed regions that suffered economic downturns after the drop in American manufacturing. The following map was pulled from a user of custom Google Maps which outlines the area typically considered in the Rust Belt.

If the Rust Belt tops in the Affordability metric, which cities are the hardest to afford? Sitting at the bottom are cities job seekers would normally find as some of the most expensive (Baltimore maybe being the exception):

  1. San Francisco, CA (10.4x)
  2. San Jose, CA (8.73)
  3. Boston, MA (6.56)
  4. Washington, D.C. (5.92)
  5. Baltimore, MD (5.31)

San Francisco leads the list as the most unaffordable city by median salary, with a score of 10.4x, more than double the average Affordability score for the 25 cities in the study. Multiples at that level (10x earnings) make it very difficult if not impossible to buy a house at the current levels. Inflation and interest rates impact affordability as well, but on salary alone you might as well rent (and find a roommate or two).

Obtainability

Besides the cost of a particular region, the next question one will normally ask is the likelihood of landing a job. This is where obtainability comes in, or, the number of people in the region competing for a fixed number of jobs. Note, the article did not elaborate on what represents the “population” in a given city, so I assumed it is the total population of working age (normally 18-65). Affordability is great to know how long it will probably take someone to pay off a house given he or she actually lands the job, but obtainability tells us how difficult (all things being equal) to solidify one of those jobs. From the 25 cities listed in the Glassdoor report, those with the highest degree of obtainability (fewest people competing per one job) are in order as follows:

  1. San Jose, CA (37.96)
  2. San Francisco, CA (48.39)
  3. Raleigh, NC (51.48)
  4. Washington, D.C. (51.67)
  5. Seattle, WA (52.89)

Again, this might not be terribly shocking, with the Bay Area, Mid-Atlantic and Seattle regions experiencing massive job growth over the past decade or so, fueled strongly by technology & banking, as well as government careers. Notice that three of the top five obtainable cities in terms of people / job are also in the top five of least affordable, a common occurrence. What was not included in the report was the kind of jobs, only the total number. However the median base salary does imply the quality of jobs in the region to an extent.

At the bottom end of this ranking, the cities with the most people competing for one job (of those in the Glassdoor study) are:

  1. Atlanta, GA (80.62)
  2. Indianapolis, IN (82.61)
  3. Houston, TX (87.18)
  4. St. Louis, MO (89.47)
  5. Memphis, TN (90.91)

Livability

Putting this all together, where is really the best city of the study to move to for a job? Ideally, someone with no ties or care for anything but affordability and likelihood of landing a job (again, only considering these 25 cities), would most likely want to go somewhere with high Affordability and high Obtainability. In other words, low multiples of each ratio. To easily determine which city is “best” from the list, I created a new metric called Livability, which combines both Affordability & Obtainability in one consumable number. To make it easier to understand in a graph, I reversed the ordering (normally smaller is better). My formula for livability is:

Livability = ABS(1 - ( (normalize(Affordability) + normalize(Obtainability)) * .5) ) )

By normalizing both variables, we can more fairly add them (Note: I weighted them equally as 1/2; depending on how someone values finding a job vs paying a house would change the weighting). The following is the resulting graph of livability by the 25 Glassdoor.com metros:


What this graph shows is in terms of ease of finding a job and owning a home, Raleigh, NC is first on the list of 25 as the city that is easiest to land a median salary job and ease of paying off a median cost home. Based on my new Livability measure, the top 5 cities from the study to live in are:

  1. Raleigh, NC
  2. Seattle, WA
  3. Austin, TX
  4. Dallas, TX
  5. Washington D.C.

Compare my list to Glassdoor’s top 5 ranking, which factors in the subjective measure “Job Satisfaction Rating”:

  1. Raleigh, NC
  2. Kansas City, MO
  3. Oklahoma City, OK
  4. Austin, TX
  5. Seattle, WA

It’s easy to see some of the similarities. Raleigh is first in both lists; I had Seattle as second while Glassdoor had it fifth; finally I rated Austin slightly higher at third instead of fourth. My bottom five cities are quite interesting:

  1. Oklahoma City, OK
  2. Houston, TX
  3. Memphis, TN
  4. St. Louis, MO
  5. San Francisco, CA

San Francisco is obviously towards the bottom simply based on the fact it is difficult to own a home. The others are heavily weighted down by weak job markets; three of the bottom five were in the cellar of the Obtainability study. Oklahoma City was in the middle of the pack on both metrics and could represent an area on the rise where housing prices outweigh job prospects. In fact, supply & demand should keep all of these values hovering near a constant sum; when job opportunities fall, so should demand for houses and therefore prices.

Availability-Obtainability Curve

One major learning I determined from this study is something I call the “Availability-Obtainability” curve, or more simply, the “AO” curve. Like supply/demand, advancer/decliner graphs in finance & economics, the AO curve provides insights into markets that may be underpriced relative their job prospects. Again, this is not a scientific study and should not be considered on its own, but the AO curve might provide job seekers an idea of where to buy housing. As I mentioned above, there are many other factors that go into relocation and where people move, but this may be a first of its kind. With that, here is the first representation of the AO curve:

For comparison’s sake, I included a reference 45 degree line; cities above the curve might be overpriced relative their job prospects and vice versa. Since there are other factors besides job opportunities most of the cities fall beneath the 45 degree line. With additional information and study (including more data points), I would expect the curve to smooth out and hover closer to the reference line. However this does again provide an interesting place to start when job & location hunting.

Conclusion

From this study what can be concluded? First, Affordability & Obtainability are just two of the factors that job seekers consider when relocating to a city for a job. As the age-old saying goes you have to love what you do otherwise it’s just work. However I believe these are two of the most important metrics to have if there is no emotional or familiar attachment to a particular location. Second, while the American Dream of owning a home is no longer the dream shared by many, renting is a derivative of owning and normally areas with stable ownership rates tend to have higher rental prices. So this study applies to those people as well. Finally, using both Availability & Obtainability, potential job seekers can construct a curve to determine under and over valued areas relative to job prospects. This can help gain an edge in long term contentment and paying off a house.

Glassdoor Study (All values & stats borrowed from their study) – http://www.glassdoor.com/blog/best-cities-jobs/
